awd_titl_txt: EAGER: An Exploration of Urban Community-Based STEM Models
awd_abstract_narration:
This project examines the growing prominence of organizations focused on Science, Technology, Education and Math (STEM) and seeks to understand how sustainability of outreach and financing play a crucial role as the nation looks to meet the increased need for workers trained in technical fields. This project seeks to explore the characteristics of STEM New Orleans Louisiana (NOLA), a community-based program targeting underrepresented K-12 students. The project will provide insights into a model of STEM learning to investigate issues of equity, accessibility and broadening participation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Community- based science program: An Exploration of an Urban Community-Based STEM Learning Model was a National Science Foundation funded (1936668) project aimed at exploring community-based STEM learning models that were designed to broaden participation of students underrepresented in STEM fields. The project team set out to identify community-based STEM programs independent of K-12 and higher education and offered programming in informal settings not affiliated with informal institutions such as science museums, etc. There was a particular interest in community-based programs that leveraged culturally relevant pedagogy as a pedagogical approach to engage students.  

Unfortunately, the project team encountered a number of setbacks from the outset. The first of which was the COVID-19 pandemic that began in the latter half of 2019 and continues to influence the way in which these programs engage with participants today. Initially, the project team planned to travel to four different, across the contiguous U.S., to observe these programs in action, interview participants, and gain access to the cur However, during the pandemic, none of the sites were accessible, and only two offered access through social media or synchronous virtual meetings. Data were collected came from virtual observations, interviews with already-established contacts, and publicly available social media posts. 

Although we were unable to fully explore these programs, our findings suggests that these program do in fact provide exposure to STEM content that is not readily offered in the formal K-12 setting.  Through these programs, participants had opportunities to meet and interact with STEM professionals – many of whom share the same race or ethnicity with the students. In this way, these programs do offer an innovative way for students to engage with content that is remarkably different from what is done in K-12 STEM classrooms. At least one of the programs made it a point to develop activities around concepts that are geographically relevant to the participating students. This allowed participating students to have some familiarity with the content being explored. There were no data, from either program, that suggested that the interests or culture of the students were considered when planning STEM learning activities. This was a point that we wanted to fully explore, particularly against Yosso’s (2005) community cultural wealth model.  The team felt that this model would be an ideal framework for community-based STEM learning programs to consider when developing STEM learning activities.  

One of the major areas of concern for this project was the sustainability of the programs. As with most programs, COVID-19 tested the sustainability of these types of programs and their ability to continue the work. Based on publicly available data, i.e., social media posts, the programs that fared well were those that had a founder or executive director who was successful in securing external funding, from both private and public funding entities, or those who were willing to expand their reach beyond the origins of the community in which they started.

 

 

References 

Yosso, T. J. (2005). Whose culture has capital? A critical race theory discussion of community cultural wealth. Race ethnicity and education, 8(1), 69-91. 

 


Last Modified: 04/04/2024
Modified by: Vanessa D Dodo Seriki
